Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: The role of freshwater-marine migratory behaviors on dispersal in Pacific Oceanic Islands fishes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many fishes are limited to marine or freshwater environments, but about 250 of 30,000 ray-finned fishes are diadromous, or migrate between fresh and saltwater, usually for reproduction purposes, e.g., Salmon and eel. This behavior is important because many small streams on oceanic islands are subject to variation. Storms, droughts, volcanic activity and pollution can often make small insular streams become uninhabitable for periods of time and can lead to local extinction of a completely freshwater species. Over time, the inability to colonize neighboring streams can lead to a species' extinction. While diadromy limits opportunities for dispersal ability to a specific life stage, many diadromous species have geographic distributions which span multiple oceans. To address these issues, this research aims to understand how variations in migration pattern affect the flow of genes across fish populations. To determine migratory behvior, otolith microchemistry techniques will be used, in collaboration with Dr. Jen-Chieh Shiao, a prominent expert in this technique at the National Taiwan University. Levels of genetic information moving between populations can then be compared to varying migration strategies.

Species will be collected from multiple streams around Taiwan (in addition to Guam and Palau). Otolith microchemistry, a technique that identifies chemical compounds in a fish's environment over the course of their life, will be used to classify fishes as diadromous, marine, or freshwater. To understand the importance of these different life-history patterns on dispersal, genetic markers will be used to infer gene flow and population structure of insular oceanic fishes. Variation in DNA sequences will be compared to understand patterns of movement between streams and islands. This project will help bridge the lingering gap between the ecological importance of variation in life history and evolutionary significance of gene flow. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with National Science Council of Taiwan.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this study is to understand the role different migratory life histories play on fishes population dynamics.  Most fishes spend their life entirely in marine or freshwater environments, however, about 250 of 30,000 ray-finned fishes are diadromous, or migrate between fresh and saltwater during specific phases of the life cycle. Life histories such as diadromy require major physiological transitions to deal with the change in salinity between marine and freshwater environments. While many studies have focused on the physiological and anatomical requirements of these transitions, little is known about this behavior's  evolutionary significance and its role in population structures. In order to understand how these behaviors affect the evolutionary trajectory of a species, molecular studies on the populations of multiple fishes are being conducted.

 

Two diadromous species of the geneus Kuhlia, K. rupestris and K. margenata, were collected with seine and dip nets from various locations around Taiwan including: Daxi River, Tamsui River, Gungfang River, river in Xiafu, Taibao city and Tainan city, the Gaomei Wetlands, multiple rivers near Changbin, Sichongxi River and Chungkung River. In addition multiple populations have been collected from rivers around Okinawa, Palau and Guam. These locations were chosen because they represent a large geographic range of both species. Additionally, comparisons within island streams and between island streams can be made. An analysis of genetic similarity between each of the sampled populations will provide information about the species population’s structure on a micro and marco scale.

 

Currently next-generation genomic DNA sequencing is being conducted to get a better understanding of the population connectivity of these species. Comparisons of the two species with other local species will be made to understand the how life history alters populations connectivity. This information will be useful in helping to understand how population’s level variation may affect the evolutionary trajectory of species. Additionally this study can shed some light as to the importance of incorporating life histories into conservations and management plans of threatened specie
